fact_list.fact_text: When driving along two-way streets, keep well to the left and as near as practicable to the boundary of the road, except when you intend to overtake or turn right.
Do not hog the middle of the road.
The keep-left rule applies to dual-carriageways.
You must not cross the centre line at bends, near the crest of a rise, or anywhere else where you cannot clearly see the road ahead.
Sometimes your path of travel may be obstructed by road works or parked vehicles.
To avoid obstruction, take extra care to ensure that your intended path is safe and clear before moving to the right.
You may cross the centre line if the roads are narrow.
You must obey the directions indicated by arrows marked in the lanes.
You must not change lanes suddenly as you may inconvenience or endanger other motorists.
When changing lanes, give sufficient warning of your intention.
Always signal in advance when changing lanes.
Failure to signal in advance could cause an accident.
In traffic hold-ups, do not ‘jump the queue’.
Trying to get ahead of others by squeezing between lanes and overtaking recklessly is dangerous.
Always be patient and have consideration for other road users.
Well before you reach a junction, make sure that you get into the correct lane for whichever direction you wish to take.
On a two-lane carriageway, keep to the left-hand lane except when overtaking.
On a three-lane carriageway, you may keep to the centre lane when the left-hand lane is occupied by slower moving vehicles.
The outer (right-hand) lane is for overtaking and emergency vehicles only.
Never overtake unless you can do so without endangering yourself or others.
Be especially careful when overtaking at night, in heavy rain, and mist.
When visibility is poor, it becomes more difficult to judge speed and distance.
Always overtake on the right, except for specific exceptions.
You may overtake on the left when the driver in front has signalled their intention to turn right.
You may overtake on the left when you want to turn left at a junction.
You may overtake on the left when traffic is moving slowly in queues and vehicles in the lanes on your right are moving more slowly than you are.
You may overtake on the left on one-way streets where vehicles may pass on either side.
After overtaking, return to the appropriate lane on the road as soon as it is safe, but do not cut in sharply in front of the vehicle you have just overtaken.
Do not overtake when you are at or approaching a pedestrian crossing, a road junction, a corner or bend, the brow of a hill, or double white lines.
Do not overtake where the road narrows.
Do not overtake if it would force another vehicle to swerve or reduce speed.
Do not overtake if in doubt.
Do not increase your speed while being overtaken.
Slow down if necessary to let the overtaking vehicle pass.
Overtaking is dangerous and should not be attempted when the car in front of you is about to overtake the car in front of it.
Overtaking is dangerous and should not be attempted when the car in front is changing from the left to the right lane in order to make a right turn.
Overtaking is dangerous and should not be attempted when you have to get into the path of oncoming traffic in order to overtake.
